message_1: Suppose we have 7 balls, each of a different color. In how many ways can we choose 3 of these balls if we want balls of every color to be represented in the choice?
message_2:
Since there are 7 balls of different colors, and we want to choose 3 balls with all different colors, we can simply use the combination formula to find the number of ways to choose 3 balls out of 7.

The combination formula is given by:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of items, k is the number of items we want to choose, and ! denotes the factorial function (e.g., 5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1).

In this case, n = 7 (total number of balls) and k = 3 (number of balls we want to choose).

C(7, 3) = 7! / (3!(7-3)!)

C(7, 3) = 7! / (3!4!)

C(7, 3) = (7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(4 × 3 × 2 × 1))

C(7, 3) = (7 × 6 × 5) / (3 × 2 × 1)

C(7, 3) = 210

So there are 210 ways to choose 3 balls of different colors from a set of 7 balls.
